Created on 20/08/2012

class pyproct.clustering.comparison.distrprob.kullbackLieblerDivergence.KullbackLeiblerDivergence(pdb_info, condensedMatrix)[source]¶

NUM_BINS = 200¶
get_calculated_KL_values()[source]¶

A simple getter...

classmethod get_matrix_data(matrix, initial_element, number_of_elements)[source]¶

A matrix generated from the concatenation of two pdbs may have 3 submatrices. First is the pairwise matrix of the first pdb, second the pairwise matrix of the second, and third is the distance matrix of pdb1 vs pdb2 (in which info is duplicated, as its itself a pairwise distance matrix). This function grabs the data of one of the two first submatrices.

@param matrix: The matrix we are talking about :/ @param initial_element: is the index of the initial element of the pdb we want to extract the data. For instance if we are working with 2 trajectories of 3 and 4 frames, indexes are [tr1:[0,1,2] tr2:[3,4,5,6]], so to extract the first submatrix data, initial_element would be 0 and number_of_elements 3. Extracting the second submatrix will need a initial_element value of 3 and a number_of_elements value of 4. @param number_of_elements: As explained above, the number of models the pdb we are working with has.

@return: A 1D numpy.array containing the submatrix data.

classmethod get_probability_histogram(data, bin_range, num_bins)[source]¶

Creates the histogram using numpy. @param data: data from which we will create the histogram (in this case the data of one of the submatrices) @param bin_range: tuple with the maximum and minimum value the sum of all distributions (not only this one) can have. @param num_bins: Number of discrete parts of the distribution.

classmethod kullback_leibler_divergence_calculation(dist1, dist2)[source]¶

Calculates the Kullback - Leibler divergence of two distributions. @param dist1: first distribution @param dist2: second distribution

@return: The Kullback-Leibler Divergence value

plot_distributions(where)[source]¶

Saves a plot of the distributions. @param where: The name of the file without extension (”.png” will be appended to the final name).

save(where)[source]¶

Saves a plot of the distributions and the actual values of them. @param where: The name of the file without extension (”.png” will be appended to the final name).

to_json(where, image_path)[source]¶

Saves the K-L values in a text file containing its json representation. @param where: The name of the file without extension (”.json” will be appended to the final name). @param image_path: Place where we have saved the image with the distribution.

pyproct.clustering.comparison.distrprob.kullbackLieblerDivergence.smoothed(distribution, small_value=1e-08)[source]¶

Applies a smoothing process to the distribution. See http://mathoverflow.net/questions/72668/how-to-compute-kl-divergence-when-pmf-contains-0s for an explanation about the problem and the solution.

@param distribution: distribution to be smoothed @param small_value: value to be set to those bins with 0 probability

@return: The smoothed distribution.
